title: theresa mays letter sacking gavin
story: NewsTheresa Mays letter sacking Gavin Williamson as Defence Secretary and his replyThe Prime Minister fired Mr Williamson over his conduct during the inquiry into the Huawei leakShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May today sacked Gavin Williamson as Defence Secretary following the leak of discussions about Huawei from a National Security Council meeting. In a brutal dismissal letter, Mrs May said she was concerned by the manner in which you have engaged with this investigation. She went on to say all other members of the cabinet had fully cooperated with the inquiry, but he had not. She went on: In our meeting this evening, I put to you the latest information from the investigation, which provides compelling evidence suggesting your responsibility for the unauthorised disclosure. No other, credible version of events to explain this leak has been identied. She concluded that she had no other option but to sack him, as she had lost confidence in him as a minister.   DOWNING STREET LONDON SWA AA THE PRIME MINISTER  May  Dear Gavin  Thank you for your time this evening. We discussed the investigation into the unauthorised disclosure of information from the National Security Council meeting on  April. This is an extremely serious matter, and a deeply disappointing one. It is vital for the operation of good government and for the UK’s national interest in some of the most sensitive and important areas that the members of the NSC — from our Armed Forces, our Security and Intelligence Agencies, and the most senior level of Government — are able to have frank and detailed discussions in full confidence that the advice and analysis provided is not discussed or ulged beyond that trusted environment. That is why I commissioned the Cabinet Secretary to establish an investigation into the unprecedented leak from the NSC meeting last week, and why I expected everyone connected to it — Ministers and officials alike — to comply with it fully. You undertook to do so. I am therefore concerned by the manner in which you have engaged with this investigation. It has been conducted fairly, with the full co-operation of other NSC attendees. They have all answered questions, engaged properly, provided as much information as possible to assist with the investigation, and encouraged their staff to do the same. Your conduct has not been of the same standard as others’. In our meeting this evening, I put to you the latest information from the investigation, which provides compelling evidence suggesting your responsibility for the unauthorised disclosure. No other, credible version of events to explain this leak has been identied. It is vital that I have full confidence in the members of my Cabinet and of the National Security Council. The gravity of this issue alone, and its ramications for the operation of the NSC and the UK’s national interest, warrants the serious steps we have taken, and an equally serious response. It is therefore with great sadness that I have concluded that I can no longer have full confidence in you as Secretary of State for Defence and a Minister in my Cabinet and asked you to leave Her Majesty’s Government. As you do so, I would like to thank you for the wider contribution you have made to it over the last three years, and for your unquestionable personal commitment to the men and women of our Armed Forces. Yours Sincerely  Theresa May   The Right Honourable Gavin Williamson CBE MP Gavin Williamsonaposs reply:Dear Prime Minister,It has been a great privilege to serve as Defence Secretary and Chief Whip in your Government. Every day I have seen the extraordinary work of the men and women of our armed forces, who go to incredible s to defend our country.I am sorry that you feel recent leaks from the National Security Council originated in my Department. I emphatically believe this was not the case. I strenuously deny that I was in any way involved in this leak and I am confident that a thorough and formal inquiry would have vindicated my position.I have always trusted my civil servants, military advisers and staff. I believe the assurances they have given me.I appreciate you offering me the option to resign, but to resign would have been to accept that I, my civil servants, my military advisers or my staff were responsible: this was not the case.Restoring public confidence in the NSC is an ambition we both share. With that in mind I hope that your decision achieves this aim rather than being seen as a temporary distraction.As I said there has been no greater privilege than working with our armed forces and I will continue to stand up for our service personnel and the superb work they do.Yours ever,Gavin

title: tories could lose 800 council
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn says bickering will cost Tories as party faces  seat wipeoutJeremy Corbyn has accused the Theresa May government of bickering while the public suffers at the hands of austerityShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsTheresa May is set to have yet another bad week "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories are on the brink of a local election meltdown tomorrow as voters go to the polls across the country. Theresa May’s party could lose around  council seats inflicting further misery on the already battered Conservatives. And the Prime Minister knows a disastrous day at the polls could hasten her departure.  Her only silver lining is that Nigel Farage’s Brexit party is not standing and UKIP is only putting up candidates in one in six seats. Speaking to the Mirror, Jeremy Corbyn accused ministers of “bickering and jostling” while the country suffered from austerity. “People don’t feel like what’s going on in Westminster has any bearing on their lives,” he said.    Voters are desperately concerned by the social care crisis, rising crime, the plight of high streets and school cuts. But Mr Corbyn added: “In their front rooms TVs have blared about the mess Theresa May has made of the Brexit negotiations and plots to depose her.”The Labour leader is hoping to show the momentum is with his party by clocking up over  gains. But he acknowledged that the elections could be “tough” for Labour too with Brexit “overshadowing” everything. And party insiders suggested polling expertsapos predictions the Tories could lose more than  seats were “way off”.  This set of elections were last fought on the day of the  general election, when turn-out was high and David Cameron won a small majority.    A lower turnout nearly always disproportionately hits the Labour vote. The elections are also predominantly in Leave-voting Tory heartlands that could punish Labour over its second referendum stance.   In a plea to voters, Mr Corbyn said: “Today people have the chance to elect caring and hardworking Labour councillors and mayors to show Theresa May and the Conservatives that after nine years of running down and cutting vital services, there is an alternative.” Some , seats are up for grabs in  councils in England. The Tories defend ,, Labour , and the Lib Dems . Labour hopes to seize Trafford, Redcar and Calderdale and leapfrog the Tories as Brighton’s biggest party.  A good night would result in the party winning Walsall, Stoke-on-Trent and Derby. Any signs of an anti-Brexit effect could come in Stockport, a minority Labour council with a big Lib Dem contingent.

, title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Tory minister has admitted the DWP dropped the ball after a scathing internal report on Universal Credit was published almost  MONTHS late.Shamefaced Alok Sharma made the confession after a November  report on the six-in-one benefit was only published in April .It showed % of people who moved from Tax Credits to Universal Credit due to a change in circumstances struggled financially at least some of the time.Yet the findings are now well out of date as several changes have been made since . And they were published too late for , ex-Tax Credit claimants who have already been moved onto UC through a change in circumstances.  Mr Sharma claimed the Department for Work and Pensionsmade a mistake in withholding the report from the public for more than a year. Today UC Director-General Neil Couling admitted the date could not be brought forward any earlier. He said his team was full of mechanics with their hands in the engine, attempting to move claimants off IT systems conceived in the late s and built in the s. He described UC as the biggest digital development in Western Europe - and warned that once aposmanaged migrationapos begins, it will happen at breakneck speed. He told MPs: “The reason why it’s tricky and I’ve asked for the time to do this to the middle of  is because you go straight to a high volume. “As soon as we switch it on, in that week the run-ons will apply to ,-odd cases. story: NewsDevious mum-of-three nicked £k from employer to take kids to DisneyworldCharlotte Clton, swindled her bosses at County Gates Ltd by disguising payments to herself worth tens of thousands of poundsShareCommentsByChris Slater:,  MAY NewsCharlotte Clton will serve at least six months behind bars for her deception "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA aposdevious and greedyapos mum swindled £, from her employer to take her kids on a trip to Disneyworld. Mother-of-three Charlotte Clton doctored payments to suppliers and staff to funnel tens of thousands of pounds into her own account.Clton wept in the dock as the judge told her she would serve at least six months behind bars for her deception, reports the Manchester Evening News.The -year-old worked as accounts manager at County Gates Ltd, a small business based at Chadkirk Industrial estate in Romiley, Stockport, that provides custom gates, railings, balconies and other metalwork. She was responsible for paying suppliers and the weekly staff wages, Minshull Street Crown Court heard. In December , a routine check of payments was carried out before the firm closed for Christmas. It was discovered that the bank account details on one payment were not that of the supplier, but Cltonaposs.    A more detailed examination revealed  fraudulent transactions disguised as wages payments or payments to suppliers. The total amount of money funnelled out of the company was said to be over £,, a sum a judge said companies of that size could aposill affordapos. Police said Clton used to the money to obtain qualications for non-surgical cosmetic procedures, which have enabled her to start up her own business as a self-employed beautician. She also spent the money on days out, eating out and even booked a family holiday to Disneyworld in the US, they added. Clton, of Dorking Close, Stockport, admitted one count of fraud at an earlier hearing. Huw Edwards, defending, said Clton made the first few payments due to her then aposdire financial positionapos, but because she aposgot away with itapos, she aposbecame greedyapos and carried on taking money, which she began to rely on. He said Clton, who has no previous convictions, was aposgenuinely remorsefulapos and urged the judge not to send her straight to prison. Mr Edwards said Clton has three children, who would be greatly affectedshe was jailed. I cannot think of a more worthy candidate to have her sentence suspended, her offending behaviour aside, he added. Clton wept in the dock as the judge, Recorder Nicholas Clarke QC, told her a -month sentence could not be suspended. She will serve half her sentence in prison and the rest on licence. He told her: You indulged yourself at the expense of your employer, who trusted you explicitly. As accounts manager you were responsible for paying suppliers and staff wages. This offence was sophisticated and involved the altering of records.    It was devious and quite deliberate. The total amount is signicant, over £,, which small family firms can ill-afford. There is a perception that fraud is a faceless crime but this case is a good example that most certainly is not. The company told police: Charlotte was a well-liked and trusted member of staff. We are shocked at the level of deception Charlotte has shown herself capable of. We had concerns because although we were busy and had plenty of customers, we were only making a minimal profit. title: how duchess cambridge handled each
story: NewsHow Duchess of Cambridge handled each post birth appearance very dferentlyFrom Prince Georges debut in  to showing off Prince Louis last year - Kate underwent a gradual transformationShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News"Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Itaposs been nearly six yearssince that hot July in  when the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge presented Prince George to the world. Now, with Meghan Markle due any day now, the spotlight has fallen once again on the rights and wrongs of expecting new royal mums to face the media hours after giving birth.Some think itaposs the price you pay for a le of immense, largely public-funded privilege. Others feel itaposs completely inhumane to ask a mum so immediately postpartum to do this. Remarkably, Kate not only did it with her firstborn, but then again with Charlotte and Louis.While a lot was obviously made of her changing style and the subtle nods to Diana , another change was playing out before our eyes. If you look back at Kateon the famous Lindo Wing steps with each of her babies, other dferences in how she handled the publicity become more apparent too. Prince George With so many new royal babies having made their debut - or about to - Georgeaposs birth on  July seems like a letime ago. Just a day after his birth, the new parents faced the press and the public outside the Lindo Wing.  The couple had delayed announcing the birth for four hours as theyaposd wanted to just enjoy spending some time with their tiny son first. When they eventually tottered outside, they were very generous with their time in the front of the cameras. Out of all of their children, William and Kate spent the longest posing for photos with George. As for why, there are a number of potential reasons.  It was a warm summer evening. George will be king one day, meaning public interest was particularly high. And, as elated, emotional, first-timers, they may have felt more inclined to show their baby off. Dressed in a polkadot Jenny Packham number, Kate did not try to hide her postpartum tummy. She paired the dress with some casual cork wedges and wore her hair in a natural, loose style.There were some signs of nerves from the new parents .Kate kept a firm hold on George, cradling him with both arms during their appearance. Only once did she release one hand to wave for photos.  Onlookers also witness a sweet and slightly fumbling handover as Kate passed George to William - and then there was the struggle fitting the car seat, which any parent can relate to. Kateaposs body language also gave away her nerves.Kateaposs feet are nearly overlapping as sheaposs standing on the stairs, body language expert Patti Wood told Good Housekeeping .This indicates that she feels the need to keep it all together. Both of them have relaxed hands but thereaposs slight gestures like the feet and forced smiles that indicate theyaposre a bit tense in this moment.    And who could blame them  Princess Charlotte Just under two years later and William and Kate are no longer first-time parents working through all the nerves and novelty of having a newborn. Kate was admitted to hospital in the early hours of the morning on May , and left later that evening.    The couple once again posed for photos but there was a marked dference from the photocall with George. Not only did Kate seem a lot more polished and preened , but she seemed a lot more confident too.    This tender moment between Will and Kate is something out of a movie, Wood said. Her fingers are locked inside his, which is her subtle way of saying aposthis moment is all about us.apos  This time, she and William spent less than two minutes in front of the camera. There was no answering questions of walkabout as there had been with George, and Kate kept hold of Charlotte the whole time - albeit cradling her with just one arm. They both appeared more poised and comfortable - and a little more businesslike.    William, this time, bossed fitting the car seat - and he even flashed a cheeky peace sign at the waiting paps. Prince Louis By the time baby Louis arrived, the Cambridges were seasoned pros at parenting - and their appearance outside the Lindo Wing proved it. There was a smaller crowd gathered outside this time - perhaps because the little prince falls slightly further down the royal ranking.  Kate was ready to face the cameras just seven hours after giving birth, and looked even more cofed, once again wearing Jenny Packham and in high heels. Perhaps mindful of the cool wind and their two eldest waiting for them at home, she and William spent just a minute and a half outside. One particularly touching shot of Kate and her new son shows them mirroring eachothersapos hand gestures.    Sure, Kate is fixing her hair from the wind but itaposs also an indicator of a strong rapport between the two, Susan Constantine, human behavioral expert and author tells Good Housekeeping. After some brief posing, the couple marched over to their car - completely confident and in sync.

story: NewsThe Rude Map of Britain reveals cheeky locations from Bell End to Titty HoAndy and Magnus Tait have spent six years planning their , mile journey across the country, finding all of the UKs smuttiest addressesShareCommentsByStephen White:,  MAY NewsAndyand MagnusTait with one of their tamer locations "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo brothers drove , miles on an epic ‘Rude Trip’ of Britain - to visit every place with a rude name. Andy and Magnus Tait spent six years planning their journey visiting streets, villages and towns with naughty titles. They stopped off at Cumwhinton, Fanny Street, Upperthong, Butthole Lane, Willey, Titty Ho and Sandyballs. They also visited Bellenden Gardens, Poundbottom, Cockermouth, Penistone, Butthole Bell End, The Knob, Lower Swell, Old Sodbury, Butcombe and Shaftesbury.    The pair also took in Shitterton, Lickfold, Fingringhoe, Slutshole Lane, Feltwell, Fanny Hands Lane, Scunthorpe, Rimswell and Wetwang. The lads spent four days on their road trip and took a selfie at  roads, town or village signs. Their remarkable tour of Britain saw them trek through at least  counties on each of the north, east, south and west coasts. The trip took six years for -year-old Andy, from Aberdeen, to meticulously map out.  He dreamed up the idea after he drove past a place called South Gash, in Fraserburgh, Aberdeenshire in  with his brother Magnus, , from Edinburgh. Andy says he couldn’t help but laugh at the signpost and ever since that day has researched the location of other amed places. He then went on to painstakingly map out a route, incorporating  stops in almost every corner of Britain. “I always enjoy going out of my way to have fun and to take things too far”, said audio engineer Andy.  “It was a lot of fun and we actually saw a lot of interesting places, he continued. “It was a bit of a slog towards the end and it was dark when we got to some places. But never at any point did we get bored. “I’d say it’s definitely an alternative was to see Britain. We just found it hilarious. We laughed our asses off at each place and that says a lot about us.” Andy and software developer Magnus set off on their journey from Bellenden Gardens, in Edinburgh, last Friday morning. They arrived back in the same street at .am yesterday morning.    He says it took him six years to convince his brother to join him on the trip after constant pestering ever since the pair passed South Gash together in . Andy chipped away at planning his route on a monthly basis over the six years, before finally packing up a few belongings, snacks for the road and wads of cash for fuel. He says the trip saw they visit some of the country’s prettiest places. The most picturesque places for him were Poundbottom and Sandyballs in the New Forest.  But his favourite out of the whole lot based on the hilarity of its name was Wilsford Cum Lake. Andy said: “I’ve had the idea for six years now. I insisted we stopped at South Gash to take a photo but Magnus didn’t fancy it. “That led to an obsession for places with funny names and six years later Magnus decided to make it up to me. “He saw the funny side of it eventually.”  Andy’s route is so well mapped out that it only took the pair between  and  minutes to drive between each stop. He said: “We went right down the west coast, along the south coast and up the east coast of England. “We have got a childish and immature sense of humour. “This is something we can tick off our bucket list.”

story: NewsStudent dismissed from university by letter fell to his death from bridgeBenjamin Murray had been told the University of Bristol had chosen to "dismiss" him from his course following his lack of attendance at lectures and at an exam, an inquest heardShareCommentsBySarah Lumley:,  MAY NewsBenjamin Murray had told officials he had been struggling to settle in, an inquest heard"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A university student suffering with anxiety fell to his death from a bridge after he was dismissed from his course by letter, an inquest heardaposFresherapos Benjamin Murray had told officials he had been struggling to settle in, his parents told the inquest today. The -year-old died in  while studying at the University of Bristol - where  students have taken their own le in the last three years. An English undergraduate, he had been told the university had chosen to dismiss him from his course following his lack of attendance at lectures and at an exam.But at an inquest into his death at Avon Coroneraposs Court his parents James and Janet Murray said they feel that the university failed their son.James, from London, told the inquest that  dferent members of staff were involved in email correspondence during Benaposs seven months at Bristol University. But he said not one face-to-face meeting was organised with Ben. The student then became confused and upset about the universityaposs decision to dismiss him from his course, it was said.  Benaposs father James told how he saw Ben for lunch the same day that his son died - just hours before Benaposs death. He said: He mentioned that Bristol Uni had written to him to say thathe didnapost engage they might remove him from the university. We discussed this, and I said thathe didnapost want to continue with university that was okay. But I told him to try and pass his exam so that he could have the summer to decide whether he wanted to leave on his own terms. After lunch I hugged him and told him I loved him, and he went back to his halls - or at least, that was what he told me. James added: I feel like that last lunch I walked into a perfect storm - not knowing that he had been kicked out already, and was being forced out his accommodation, his home, the following week. In a statement to the hearing, Benaposs parents said: As a family we believe time was a critical factor in Benaposs death. He spent far too long aposstruggling in the waterapos, so to speak. Much earlier intervention was needed and should have happened. Ben was not even referred to the university halls welfare officer, as he was not considered at risk. But in the workplace, you do not just send letters to sack people. There are proper, face-to-face procedures that should be followed. For a -year-old fresher to be kicked out of his first year course without a face-to-face meeting is unacceptable and extraordinary. If a -year-old says he is anxious, and is not attending lectures, you should immediately take action, and not just send him links. What further signs do you need that something is wrong  We believe Bristol Uni failed on a number of occasions with the lack of pastoral care given to Ben. Benaposs social media messages to his university friends had suggested he was suffering from depression and they urged him to speak to student services. He had twice told senior tutor Charles Gunter that he was not feeling well, and had been struggling to connect, an inquest heard.  But although Mr Gunter emailed Ben information on how to register with student services, no checks were made on whether Ben actually did so. The inquest heard that Ben was sent a letter dated February , informing him that he was being dismissed from his course due to lack of engagement. This followed senior tutor Charles holding a telephone meeting with Ben on December , during which Ben expressed he was struggling to settle in at uni and struggling to connect. Mr Gunter said: I told him it was quite natural to feel a little bit unsettled. I established that he hadnapost registered with the uni health services, and sent him information on that and how to register. I wanted to make sure that he was aware that there was support. After Ben missed an exam in January, Mr Gunter got back in touch with him and advised him to fill out an exam absence form, as Ben once again told him he had been unwell. Mr Gunter added: At the start of February the next teaching block started, and for the second term in a row Ben did not complete registration for that teaching block. I asked ious tutorshe was attending classes, and I received mix replies. Some said he had been to lectures, others said he had come to some of them. The situation became one that required attention. This was not just Ben missing one or two classes, or failing to hand in an assignment. He had failed to engage and had not passed  credits. At a faculty meeting at the start of February, the university Arts Faculty made the decision that Ben be dismissed from his course. However, despite Mr Gunter contacting the Humanities School education doctor, Lesel Dawson, to try and raise Benaposs attendance, the senior tutor said that the dismissal letter of February  was the last contact the English School had with Ben. He said: I had hoped that Benaposs issue was just an issue with settling in in the first term. I escalated Benaposs case to Dr Dawson because I felt I had already made contact and had done what I could. I find that sometimesa student no longer wants to engage with one member of staff, perhaps talking to a new member of staff can help. However, Dr Dawson proposed a meeting with Ben on March  - two days after Benaposs appeal period to remain at the university would have passed, the inquest heard. And, the very day before his death, Benaposs friend Stefan Lossev said Ben messaged him, concerned and confused about an email informing him he had to move out of his halls the following week. Ben wrote to Stefan: I feel like Iaposm leaving the Matrix or unplugging, to which Stefan replied: Donapost kill yourself, please. The inquest heard that Ben had been known to take recreational drugs - and it was believed to be this that had contributed to his poor attendance at university lectures. Ben had started at University of Bristol in September  - but Bristol was not his first choice of uni, the inquest heard. He had hoped to go to Edinburgh University with his long-term girlfriend - and his mother Janet said that the long distance relationship was quite hard for both of them. Benaposs mum said: Ben was in a transition year. He was in his first year, having come through clearing, and so was under academic pressure. He was also facing bereavement, having lost both his grandparents to cancer  months before his own death. They were very important in Benaposs le, and he would definitely have felt that loss. I suggested that he see a counsellor to talk about his feelings around that, but he didnapost want to. Ben was in good health and was not on any medication that I was aware of. When he ed to the university after his first-year Christmas holidays, he said he was going to eat more of a plant-based diet, and be more conscious about the food he ate. story: NewsToddler diagnosed with rare condition after mum notices odd feature in photoChloe Storer, , was taking a picture of her -month-old son Jake when she spotted the right side of his face appeared to be paralysed - before he was diagnosed with a condition affecting only  people worldwideShareCommentsByJess Grieveson-SmithAbigail OLeary:,  MAY NewsChloe with her son Jake, who was diagnosed with a condition so rare, only  people are believed to suffer from it in the world "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA toddler was diagnosed with a rare condition after his mum noticed an odd facial feature in a photograph. story: NewsMan nearly loses foot after flesh eating bacteria causes horric injuriesWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Barry Briggs posted photos on social media showing his foot and shin without any skin after he fell ill on a boating trip in Tampa, FloridaShareCommentsByChris Murphy:,  MAY NewsLuckily doctors were able to save Barry Briggs foot"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man almost lost his foot after flesh eating bacteria tore away at it while he was on holiday. Barry Briggs, from Ohio, fell ill after a boating trip in Tampa, Florida and ended up with horric injuries.He raised awareness of his illness through Facebook , posting raw images of what the flesh-eating bacteria can do - leaving his foot and shin without any skin. Barry was rushed into Miami Valley Hospital in Dayton after ing home where he then spent  days undergoing extensive treatment for the terrying condition.He underwent skin grafts and was put on several dferent antibiotics, but eventually he was lucky that doctors were able to save his foot.    Barry was diagnosed with necrotizing fasciitis caused by group a Streptococcus bacteria which usually enters through a small wound. Necrotizing fasciitis is a rare infection and there are  to  cases in the U.S. annually, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. However, researchers told CNN that they also believe this is an underestimate due to cases being underreported. The news channel said Barryaposs story came just days after a Florida man was hospitalised at Tampa General Hospital, also for a flesh-eating bacterial infection he contracted while fishing in the Gulf of Mexico. Mike Walton said he was poked by a fishing hook  miles off the coast of Palm Harbor.  I had like little blisters starting to form on my hand and you could watch like sweat beads coming up on side of the hand, and then they just turned black, he said. Doctors told Mike he’s lucky to be alive, and lucky to have his arm. “When you look down and you can see your own tendons, back of your hand and your bone going up your arm,” Mike said, “that makes it real.” Walton is now recovering at home and will have to be treated with antibiotics for the next month.

He clambered on to an external air conditioner unit as the inferno ravaged his familyaposs flat in Russia. The petried child, named Denis, was heard pleading in anguish mama help me - but she was not at home. A resident of the block, who witnessed the drama, said: “His screams broke my heart.” The youngster was home alone after school in Samara city when the flames tore through his eight floor apartment. Unable to let himself out of the flat’s outer door, and choking from smoke, he climbed onto one of two air conditioner units, the one furthest from the flames.    A hair-raising video shows Denis crouching on top of the air conditioner - and at one point precariously peering down the the ground below. He held tightly to the window frame, but had also undergone training as a young climber - which may have saved his le. A worried eyewitness called Anastasia said: “The boy was home alone.  “The fire was very strong, flames were coming outside from the balcony. “The kid had nothing  to do but climb out of the window and crouch on the air conditioner. “We feared that the air conditioner would break off and fall.”  Luckily the unit stayed put and a firefighter eventually got into his flat and plucked the child to safety. Earlier rescuers had tried to raise a ladder to the boy but it got stuck in trees next to the block. After being alerted to the fire, the boy’s father had rushed home and let fireman into the flat. Anastasia said: “His parents arrived at the same time as the firefighters. “Thank God, the child is okay, just very scared. “He is now in the ambulance wrapped in a blanket having tea.” The boy was taken to hospital for serious smoke inhalatinon. The firefighter who rescued him, Evgeny Gulyaikin, said: “We were in breathing apparatus because the apartment was heavy in smoke.  “We entered the big room, where the sofa was already burning. “I and my partner rushed to the bedroom where the boy was outside the window. “He saw us, I grabbed him tightly. “I was so afraid to drop him - the height was eight floors. “I brought him in through there window. “I immediately took him out of the apartment block and handed him to medics. “The boy, of course, was in shock. And for us it was very worrying.” The boy’s parents had been at work when the fire ignited, said reports. An investigation into the cause is underway. Some  firefighters were involved in extinguishing the fire, with  residents needing to be evacuated.

title: airlines given chance to bid for contract for flights between dundee and london
story: Airlines are being invited to bid for the right to run Dundee’s flight route to London.A new -month contract has been put out to tender by Dundee City Council, seeking an operator for a twice-daily weekday flight as well as a singleservice to and from the capital on a Sunday.According to the contract, London is defined as “any airport within a -minute rail journey from to a London Zone  station and designated as London according to IATA city code”.It means flights to London from Dundee could potentially switch from Stansted to airports such as Luton or Southend, should the winning bidder chose to redirect the route.Tenders for consideration need to be submitted by June .The invitation for airlines to provide a twice-daily connection between Dundee and London comes only a month after the Tele revealed that air links between the two cities could be set for a shake-up, after it emerged funding for the current Stansted route is only to be available until later this year.The local authority has pledged £, to support the route as part of a public service obligationpackage agreed between itself, the Department for Transport, Transport Scotland and route operator Loganair.It also comes a week after Loganair announced it would not be introducing its new fleet of planes to the Dundee to Stansted route.Alison Henderson, chief executive of Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, said the invitation for the tenders was a sign that there was a commitment to the Dundee-London route.Ms Henderson said: “This is an important route for tourism and business, linking Dundee not only with London but hopefully with an airport that connects to other airports outwith the UK.“Ideally we would like to see flights from Dundee to an airport that provides a central onward hub where out of the UK.“Air travel is hugely important both for business and tourism in Dundee.“Dundee businesses are very keen to see regular flights to London and would welcome flights to an airport hub.“We are hoping for the right flights, to the right locations at the right price to be put in place as quickly as possible.”Dundee City Council and airport operators Highlands and Islands Airports Limited were approached for comment but had not responded at the time of going to press.

title: aberdeen uni study aims to shape information given to pregnant women across the uk
story: A study by an Aberdeen University lecturer is set to influence the information women are given before giving birth across the whole of the NHS.Researchers are investigating what information mothers-to-be want to be made available, so they can make informed choices on childbirth.The study is being led by Dr Mairead Black, a senior clinical lecturer at Aberdeen University, and a practising obstetrician consultant at Aberdeen Maternity Hospital.The study, which is funded by both the university and the British Medical Research Council, is being carried out because current guidelines are out of date.To investigate opinions, Dr Black is appealing for women to come forward to contribute.She said: “The information that pregnant women get can dfer from location to midwe, and it is clear there is no guidance on the information they get when it comes to vaginal births.“This isn’t about preferring vaginal birth or C-section, it is about understanding what information women want. We do have the skills to estimate the likelihood of a C-section for vaginal births and that information is not being shared with women. One of the outcomes of the study is to see whether women want to know that.”The study is expected to take a couple of months with it set to be published in medical journals by the end of the year.The end result is for it to hopefully influence the guidelines that midwives and doctors abide by.Focus groups of up to eight women each will take place on May -.Any women who would like to take part must be over the age of  and have had a baby at any time, and women who plan to have a baby in the future.Dr Black added: “We are also particularly interested in getting information from older women who have maybe given birth years ago to investigate whether they would have wanted to know of the long-term side-effects of childbirth.”To register your interest in the study email Dr Black on Mairead.black@abdn.ac.uk

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

title: community-support-for-new-mobile-mast-in-ettrick-valley
story: PLANS for a telecommunications tower in the Ettrick Valley have been met by a wave of support from local residents.Warrington-based WHP Telecoms has applied to SBC to erect a m-high G tower on Deephope Hill, just off the B road that runs between Eskdalemuir and Ettrick.The plans have attracted  letters of support from local residents, with most citing the current lack of mobile phone signal as a detriment to both the quality of le in the valley and the ability of businesses to thrive.One supporter, Ogilvie Jackson, of Selkirk, writes: ldquoOur valley has waited a long time to get reliable telecommunications. This mast should provide an lsquoemergency servicersquo for all the local residents and businesses should our land lines fail, as they frequently do.ldquoThere have been many occasions when accidents have happened with no means of getting help.ldquoThis will also be a great asset to tourists and traffic passing through our valley.The local branch of the National Farmers Union, which counts  members, has also thrown its weight behind the proposals.In a support letter, Selkirk branch secretary Rory Murray writes: ldquoIt is vital that in todayrsquos connected world, basic services now include the provision of a reliable mobile network, and not just for the obvious benefits to rural safety, should people be stranded without signal.ldquoA solid G signal will transform many agricultural-based businessrsquo ability to complete basic tasks that are now exclusively online, as the time constraints poor mobile phone signal and broadband signal places on rural businesses is a very real worry for our members.Despite this, Scottish Borders Council has received nine letters of objection to the plans, with objectors citing the height of the mast, the impact on the landscape and the potential detrimental impact on property prices.Mr Brian Russell, of Selkirk, writes in his objection letter: ldquoThat the Ettrick valley must have mobile masts is disappointing to those of us who came here to escape such things.ldquoOf course escape is now becoming impossible anywhere on this island, but at the very least we had hoped to be allowed to live far enough away from a base station not to be adversely affected.ldquoHealth concerns for masts and cell phones are largely discounted now, but itrsquos as well to remember that the questionable safety of very profitable technologies may not come out for decades after their introduction, e.g. in the s and s there was widespread use of agrochemicals. I was a farmer at that time and was told they were perfectly safe. Many of the chemicals we were using then have now been banned as unsafe for one reason or another.ldquoI fear the same sort of thing will happen with mobile technologies, the overuse of which masts like this one will encourage ndash technologies which are described as essential but are more often than not simply recreational or convenient.In a submission to council planners, the developers have tried to address some of the issues raised by the objectors.Damian Hosker, the principal planner at WHP Telecoms, writes: ldquoG connectivity enables iniduals and businesses to work and ecommerce effectively from home.ldquoThis means that car travel can be reduced which has a positive effect on the environment.ldquoMobile connectivity creates a sustainable community and promotes environmental issues.ldquoThe proposal is set against the backdrop of the forest. The screening could not be more prominent. WHP will, however, paint the installation green or brown or whatever colour the local planning authority wishes to see.ldquoThe value of property is not a planning issue, however, in an age where connectivity is ever more important for e-commerce, including: real-time tax s education health services requirement to attract tourists social wellbeing and emergencies there is expected to be a positive value to property as a result of being connected.ldquoNo connectivity in the UK is not acceptable to purchasers in the st century.As a result of the number of objections received, the application will be decided by councillors sitting on the Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee.The committee is due to meet on Monday, April  to deliberate on the proposals.

title: community-group-targets-steading-to-ease-ettrick-housing-demand
story: PLANS are in place for a community development company to buy a redundant steading in the Ettrick Valley to ease housing pressures.With many farm and estate cottages being sold over the past decade or so, affordable rentable accommodation in the rural valleys south of Selkirk has dwindled.The Ettrick and Yarrow Community Development Companyhope to reverse the trend by buying Kirkhope Steading, outside of Ettrickbridge, and convert the buildings into inexpensive homes to rent.EYCDC have also launched a housing survey to identy the demand for affordable housing in the area.The group have commissioned Rural Housing Scotland to independently run the survey to gauge opinion on affordable rent, buying prices, size and type of home required.A paper copy of the survey, along with a reply paid envelope, can be found in the Post Office in Selkirk, Honey Cottage Caravan Park shop in Ettrick, the Cross Keys pub in Ettrickbridge and from the Gordon Arms in Yarrow.The survey form can also be filled in online at https:www.surveymonkey r TNDLDIn , a full survey was carried out which highlighted a need for more affordable housing in the Ettrick and Yarrow Valleys.And it is thought the need has increased signicantly during the past  years.Project Manager of EYCDC, Vicky Davidson said: ldquoWe are concerned that the lack of affordable housing is impacting on the number of children living in the valleys, with fewer families and young people able to find somewhere to live."We are urging anyone who might be interested in living in the valleys but do not think they are able to find a suitable house, at an affordable rent, to complete the housing survey as soon as possible."And to pass on the survey link to anyone who might like toto live there now or within the next couple of yearsthere was an affordable option available."The EYCDCs plans for Kirkhope Steading include some workspace areas and potential office units as well as rentable housing.Funding has been provided by the Scottish Land Fund to carry out an independent valuation, get a structural engineers report and to prepare some architect options for the site.This work is now complete and it was presented to a public meeting in Ettrickbridge on April .The proposal is to start work on the site in the beginning of  and be at completion during spring the following year.For more information contact info@ettrickandyarrow.org.uk

title: council-to-chip-in-extra-42k-for-hawick-regeneration-scheme
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has agreed to chip in an extra pound, for a Hawick regeneration scheme, in order to receive a million pound grant from Scottish ministers.The local authority has already been awarded pound.m from Historic Environment Scotland to fund the Hawick Conservation Area Regeneration Scheme .However, the council intended to provide just pound, to the pot, to acquire a pound.m grant, but instead has had to stump up an extra pound, in order to secure pound.m.Along with private sector contributions of pound,, the project will have a budget of pound.m to go towards restoring shop fronts and historic buildings in the town centre.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council executive committee on Tuesday, April , councillors waved through the extra money and emphasised the positives the CARS scheme will bring to Hawick.Hawick and Hermitage councillor George Turnbull told the meeting: ldquoThis is a great news item for Hawick and will help with the town centre regeneration.ldquoIrsquod just like to publicly record my thanks to the team which has put in so much work to achieve this, I wish the project well and every success over the next five years.Kelso and District councillor Tom Weatherston, who has experienced the CARS scheme in Kelso, added: ldquoI welcome this as great news for Hawick. Talking from experience, the biggest problem building in Kelso didnrsquot get done because we couldnrsquot get hold of the owners and get them on board.ldquoMy advice would be thatthere is an owner who canrsquot afford the  per cent contribution then Irsquod say they need to try hard to help the owners and identy other sources of money to help them.A similar scheme has already been completed in Selkirk, where pound.m of public sector funding was invested in the town between  and .Over that period, the number of at risk buildings in Selkirkrsquos town centre has reduced from seven to two, average footfall has risen from a low of  to , and the percentage of vacant shops has reduced to below the Scottish Bordersrsquo average.Hawick, on the other hand, has seen a marked deterioration in its town centre.Average weekly footfall has declined, year on year, from , in  to current levels of ,, and the latest retail audit in December  showed there were  vacant units in the town centre.Furthermore,  of those units have been vacant for over a year, and there are currently seven lsquoat riskrsquo buildings within the historic centre.

title: tapestry-construction-contract-cost-300k-more-than-planned
story: A STIRLING-based construction firm was awarded the contract to build the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor centre in Galashiels earlier this month.But the contract is costing almost pound, more than originally anticipated.Ogilvie Construction Ltd won the tendering process, against three other companies, to deliver the construction phase of the pound. million project at the top of Channel Street.Scottish Borders Council initially pencilled in an estimated cost of pound. million for the main construction phase.But the contract which was awarded earlier this month comes in at just short of pound. million.Despite the hike, bosses at Scottish Borders Council are confident that add-ons in the contract will keep them within budget.A spokesman explained: "ldquoThe pound. million identied was a pre-tender estimate for the construction works element of the project only and was included in the initial contract notice purely as a guide for the contractors competitively tendering for the project.ldquoThis estimated cost did not include, for example, the novation of the design team costs, which are fixed, or the project allocation of optimism bias and contingency.ldquoNot all of the projectrsquos risk provisions are included in the initial contract notice as the council needs to achieve the most competitive and economically advantageous tender in an open market procurement processes, while also having the ability to afford market fluctuation for a bespoke construction project in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThese provisions have allowed us to award the contract at pound,,, which remains within our affordability cap for the construction element while maintaining the overall project budget of pound. million.The construction contract is for building the new visitor centre as well as refurbishing the adjacent B-listed Post Office.The Ogilvie Group is regarded as one of Scotlands most successful family owned businesses, having been operational for  years and now employing over  people.

title: local-authority-launches-pioneering-eco-friendly-car-hire-in-the-borders
story: A PIONEERING new motoring project has hit the road in the Scottish Borders.A fleet of brand-new, low emission Toyota Yaris hybrids have arrived in several Borders towns.And you can drive the eco-friendly vehicles for as little as pound. an hour or pound per day.The scheme is being delivered by Scottish Borders Council in partnership with E-Car Club.Councillor Simon Mountford told us: ldquoWe already have a successful partnership with E-Car Club to use Toyota Hybrids as pool cars for our staff."As a result of this we have seen more shared journeys by employees, a reduction in business mileage claims and lower emissions."This next stage, which allows members of the public to join a car club scheme, is hugely exciting."Vehicles are available to book across the Borders and I believe many of our local residents will take advantage of this when they need access to a car for a few hours or even a full day.The vehicles are specially adapted to include an RFID card access system, meaning the cars can be booked online or through the free E-Car Club mobile app.Bookings can be made for anyof time over one hour, and insurance is even included in the price.Patrick Cresswell, Managing Director at E-Car Club, commented: ldquoWe are delighted to give Borders residents the opportunity to integrate low emission vehicles into their everyday lives through E-Car which offers a self-service, low cost and low emission car club."Itrsquos a flexible solution for drivers who donrsquot want to commit to car ownership but need access to a car from time to time."We hope this scheme will encourage car owners to consider using the service as an alternative to vehicle ownership. And that should result in fewer cars on the road, and ultimately reducing emissions and congestion.The cars are parked in Peebles, Eyemouth, Duns, Kelso, Galashiels, Hawick and Newtown St Boswells, in allocated spaces prepared by Scottish Borders Council.As the vehicles double up as local authority pool cars they are only available in the evenings and overnight between pm and am from Monday to Wednesday.But they are for hire anytime from pm on Thursday through to am on Monday.As the vehicles are hybrid, they come with two power sources - a petrol engine and an electric motor.The majority of Toyota Hybrids are self-charging which means that every moment you are driving, your battery is charging even when slowing down.This is thanks to technology like the regenerative braking system, which recovers energy that would normally be lost and stores it in the battery for later use.And because they are all self-charging hybrids, their batteries never need to be plugged in.E-Car Club is promoting a special introductory offer to coincide with the launch which includes FREE letime membershipplus pound free driving credit.Simply visit: www.ecarclub join and enter code: WELCOMESB to claim this offer.

title: selkirk-primaries-set-for-boundary-change
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is set to consult on the catchment areas for two Selkirk primary schools.Following a decline in the number of pupils at Yarrow Primary School, council officers are looking at altering the catchment area to include homes that are currently within Philiphaugh Community Schoolrsquos catchment.The plans would mean that pupils from Yarrowford and Broadmeadows, to the west of Selkirk, would attend Yarrow Primary School instead of Philiphaugh School, which is in town.A report, due to go before Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive meeting on Tuesday  April, explains that a consultation will be carried out with parents prior to any boundary changes.The author of the report, interim service director for children and young people Stuart Easingwood, writes: ldquoThe proposed consultation will seek views on whether there is support for the proposal to amend the catchment areas.ldquoIt is not considered that the proposal will have a material impact on Philiphaugh Community School.ldquoThe number of children in the area under consideration area is relatively low and the Philiphaugh roll has been at a consistent level for a number of years.ldquoThere are currently  pupils at the school which equates to occupancy of %. The average occupancy over the last ten years has been  percent.ldquoIf there is a positive response to the proposal, and a formal recommendation is made to councillors to amend the catchment, it is proposed that pupils, from the Yarrowford and Broadmeadows area, currently attending Philiphaugh, can decide which school they would like to attend and council funded transport will be provided.ldquoThis arrangement will also apply to any future siblings.The consultation,approved by councillors on Tuesday, will run throughout May, culminating in two public meetings on Thursday, may , at Yarrow Primary School and Philiphaugh Community Schools, at .pm and .pm respectively.

title: beauty-students-hope-to-nail-a-place-in-national-qualifiers
story: BORDERS College Beauty Therapy students are hoping to make it through to the National Qualiers of the Beauty Therapy World Skills Competition.Students, Connie Lothian, along with model Kayleigh Scott, and Chloe Thomson, along with model Caitlan McGregor, study on the Beauty Therapy Level  course.The students have spent several weeks brushing up their skills and preparing for the competition, which focuses on the hand and face categories.The initial part of the competition started at the end of last month and involved the students submitting a photographic entry for initial assessment.They spent the day preparing their models to a high standard before professional photographer Phil Wilkinson was invited in to photograph the finished results.Phil spent the afternoon setting up ious photo shoots, which highlighted the best of their work, with the final pictures then submitted to the competition for assessment.The work of the students is now in the hands of the judges, and they face an anxious wait to seethey have been invited to the National Qualiers, which will take place this summer.If they qualy they will be invited to participate in the UK National Final at the NEC in November this year, as part of WorldSkills UK LIVE, the UKs largest interactive apprenticeships, skills and careers event.Heather Fisher, Curriculum Learning Manager, commented: ldquoFollowing on from the recent success of the Hairdressing and Fashion Make-up students at the AHT finals in Blackpool, we thought it would be a great idea for the Beauty Therapy students to be entered in to their own competition.ldquoThe students have been working exceptionally hard over the last month or so and their efforts have shown some excellent results.ldquoThe work the students created on the day of the photo shoot was outstanding and the final photographs highlighted this.ldquoWe should know whether we have qualied or not by May  and look forward to hearing from the judges. Fingers crossed we make it!Lecturer Gail Pow added: "This is a great opportunity for the students to showcase their skills.ldquoThe work they have put in to the competition is second to none and we hope they can secure a place in the next stage.ldquoThe photo shoot was a great experience for both students and lecturers and we are very excited to hear the feedback from the judges."

title: hawick-shoppers-supermarket-sweep-bags-500-for-foodbank

Thank you to ALDI for the opportunity!ALDI held the competition to mark the th anniversary of the opening of their first store in Scotland.Janice Cambridge from the Salvation Army Hawick Foodbank, is delighted with the donation.She said: "The ALDI Supermarket Sweep has generated an amazing amount of money for our foodbank."Caroline has even promised to donate some of the food she grabbed on the trolley dash to our charity."On behalf of the Salvation Army Hawick Foodbank, I would like to say thank you to both ALDI and Caroline for making this generous donation possible.This year ALDI is opening eight new stores across Scotland, creating an additional  jobs by the end of .Richard Holloway, Regional Managing Director for Scotland, added: ldquoThe ALDI supermarket sweep is now a firm favourite across the country and this time it was the turn of Caroline from Hawick to take part."During the five-minute sweep at our Commercial Street store, Caroline managed to snap up a whole load of ALDI treats for herself and whatrsquos more, raise an incredible amount for the Salvation Army Foodbank in Hawick.

title: craig-keeps-it-in-the-family-with-standard-bearer-appointment
story: No Standard Bearer in Selkirkrsquos history can possibly have beenbetter prepared than Craig Monks.Not only is the -year-old fencer following in the footsteps of his grandfather, Drysdale, dad, Keith, and older brother, Rory, but his boss, James Cheyne, was also a Royal Burgh Standard Bearer in .Craig, who has been an Attendant four times since , couldnrsquot hide his delight after being carried around the streets of his ancient hometown.He told us: ldquoIrsquove been brought up with the Common Riding since I was a wee boy.ldquoIt wasnrsquot just Selkirk Common Riding, me and my brothers were dragged round every festival every year.ldquoI live in a house where everyone loves the Common Riding and therersquos always plenty of advice on offer.ldquoEven when I go to work Irsquove got James telling me what to expect.ldquoIrsquove waited a long time for this and so far itrsquos been unbelievable ndash nothing has ever compared to that moment the doors opened and I became the Standard Bearer.Hundreds had gathered in the Market Place to witness Standard Bearer elect Monks hoisted shoulder-high emerging from the Town Hall.And standing above on the balcony were parents, Keith and Iona, along with brothers, Rory and Kieran.Despite the threatening grey skies the rain stayed away. Selkirk Silver and Selkirk Flute bands, as always, created the traditional atmosphere that goes hand-in-hand with Appointment Night.And the foot followers were in good voice.Following the tour of the town, Standard Bearer elect Monks was joined by his  Attendants outside the Appointment Night Concert at the Victoria Halls.Adam Nichol, , Liam Cassidy, , Andrew McColm, , and -year-old Conall Fairbairn will have the honour of following Standard Bearer Monks around the Marches in June.Also preparing for June is the recently appointed Provost.Like Standard Bearer elect Monks, Keith Miller has a fine Common Riding pedigree, having been the Weavers Standard Bearer  years ago as well as holding the position of Deacon from  to .And he admits hersquos excited about what lies ahead.Provost Miller said: ldquoI know Craig and he will do a great job as Standard Bearer.ldquoMy own son, Darren, is also the Weavers Standard Bearer this year.ldquoItrsquos going to be a busy and enjoyable year for all of us.ldquoIrsquom honoured to be Provost and itrsquos been so far so good.Selkirk Common Riding takes place on Friday, June .
